text: Sponsored Content Bee pollen has been all over social media in the last year, with people claiming the benefits range from combatting menstrual and hormonal issues to increasing the size of “the girls.” While there’s something to many bee pollen’s benefits, the quality ranges wildly between products. Like many supplements that go through a boom period, there are a lot of poor-quality imitations on the market with next to no brand credibility or testing for purity, but that does have an excellent website. Fortunately, if you’re wondering if bee pollen is for you, we have a list of the few companies that can be trusted to deliver the goods. Thus, you can get the health benefits of bee pollen without wasting your money on honey-colored sawdust. It’s also important to note that the compounds in bee pollen vary depending on the plant source and the season it was collected. For example, bee pollen collected from pine plants has approximately 7% protein, while pollen collected from date palm packs closer to 35% protein. The minerals and vitamins vary depending on the bee pollen as well. And, of course, people with a pollen allergy should avoid bee pollen. Different Forms of Bee Pollen There are essentially four different forms of bee pollen available: dried bee pollen, pollen in pill form, and then fresh and freeze-dried bee pollen, sometimes called bee pearl or bee bread, which are the ones you want. Freeze drying retains all nutrients, amino acids, and phytoestrogens and is much more easily stored; it’s also often what people mean when talking about fresh bee pollen. Dried bee pollen (unless it’s freeze-dried) is collected in its fresh form but undergoes a drying process that significantly reduces its nutrient values. Pollen in pill form is also dried and often contains more fillers than pollen, providing fewer health benefits. It’s also worth noting that royal jelly provides many benefits of bee pollen, so the best bee products contain a good amount. Kittie Bee Pearl contains the original royal jelly and beeswax, which are responsible for many benefits of bee pollen, especially for the immune system. Kittie does standardize for the flavonoids (the compounds that have any impact on health) such as quercetin, kaempferol, and apigenin, as well as the phenolic acids like ferulic acid and coumaric acid. This is the good stuff that makes bee pollen work. The other good thing about Kittie Bee Pearl is that it’s dosed correctly, which aligns with the few studies on bee pollen. Maximize all potential health benefits with 2500mg of bee pollen and 500mg of royal jelly. This, in theory, covers everything from seasonal allergies and menstrual issues to antioxidants, heart and liver health, and even wound healing. - Pros - Reputable brand - Good dosage - Includes royal jelly, too Cons - Only available from their [website](https://becomingtrendy.com/kittie-formula) Greenbow – Best Certified Organic Been Pollen While it is technically quite challenging to guarantee a bee pollen product is 100% organic (because bees collect pollen from all over the place, and they don’t know if the flowers have been sprayed or not), Greenbow is as good as you’re going to get on that front. Its formula taps into the natural benefits of bee pollen to provide relief without the need for artificial additives. They offer a combined supplement of bee pollen and other ingredients for the same price. We know we’re gushing about them, but we struggled to find three good brands for this list. Pros - Reputable brand Cons - Overpriced for what it is Choosing the Best Bee Pollen Supplement When selecting a bee pollen supplement, several factors should be considered to ensure you get a high-quality product that meets your needs. Here are the top considerations: Freshness and Source Freshness is crucial when it comes to bee pollen. Look for a reputable brand that keeps their bee pollen refrigerated or frozen during storage and transportation. Generally, Spanish bee pollen is considered the gold standard, although that’s not essential. Fresh bee pollen should dissolve into a powder when touched, while dried pollen will remain in its granular form with a rugged exterior shell. The freeze-dried powder is usually fine, but it must be frozen. Additionally, consider the source of the bee pollen. Opt for bee pollen sourced from reputable beekeepers prioritizing sustainable and ethical practices. Quality Control and Testing Choose a bee pollen supplement that undergoes rigorous quality control and testing processes. The manufacturer should test the pollen for purity, ensuring it is free from contaminants such as pesticides, heavy metals, and microbial pathogens. Look for supplements that have third-party certifications or adhere to industry standards to ensure the highest quality and safety. Storage and Packaging Proper storage and packaging are essential to maintain bee pollen’s freshness and potency. Ensure the supplement is stored in a well-sealed container to prevent exposure to moisture and air. Some brands may also offer individually sealed packets for added convenience and freshness. Recommended Dosage Follow the manufacturer’s recommended dosage instructions. Start with a small amount and gradually increase the dosage to assess your tolerance and response. It’s important not to exceed the recommended dosage to avoid potential adverse effects. Additional Ingredients Some bee pollen supplements may contain additional ingredients, such as vitamins, minerals, or other herbal extracts. Consider your specific health needs and preferences when choosing a supplement with extra ingredients. Read the product label carefully to ensure you know all the ingredients included. Bee Pollen FAQs Here are some common questions about bee pollen and their answers: Q: Can Bee Pollen Be Used as a Weight Loss Aid? A: Bee pollen has not been proven effective as a weight loss aid. While nutrient-dense and may support overall health, it should not be relied upon as a solution. A balanced diet and regular exercise are essential for sustainable weight management. Q: Is Bee Pollen Safe for Children? A: Bee pollen is not recommended for children under two due to the risk of allergic reactions. For older children, it is advisable to consult with a pediatrician before introducing bee pollen into their diet. Q: Can I Take Bee Pollen if I Am Pregnant or Breastfeeding? A: If pregnant or breastfeeding, consult a healthcare professional before taking bee pollen. While bee pollen is generally safe, individual circumstances may warrant caution. Q: Can I Take Bee Pollen if I Have Asthma or Allergies? A: Individuals with asthma or allergies to pollen or bee products should exercise caution and consult a healthcare professional before consuming bee pollen. Bee pollen can potentially trigger allergic reactions in susceptible individuals. Q: How Should Bee Pollen Be Stored? A: Fresh bee pollen should be stored in a well-sealed container in the refrigerator or freezer to maintain its freshness and nutrient content. Dried bee pollen should be stored in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight. Q: Does Bee Pollen Help With Allergy Relief? Bee pollen is often considered a potential natural remedy for alleviating allergy symptoms. It is purported to desensitize the body to allergens.
